claim: In the U.K., you can protect yourself against claims of copyright infringement by not making any money off the copyrighted work.

supporting.text: Under U.K. copyright law, infringement occurs regardless of financial gain, as it is based on unauthorized use of protected work.

attacks.text: Under U.K. copyright law, infringement occurs regardless of financial gain, as it is based on unauthorized use of protected work.
Some exceptions under 'fair dealing' provisions allow limited use of copyrighted works without permission, even if unauthorized.
Fair dealing exceptions are narrowly defined and do not cover most unauthorized uses, maintaining the general rule of infringement.
Non-commercial use (e.g., personal, educational) may reduce penalties or lead to lighter enforcement, even if technically infringing.
Reduced penalties do not negate infringement, and rights holders can still pursue legal action regardless of commercial intent.

supporting.text: The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 does not exempt non-commercial use from constituting infringement.

attacks.text: The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 does not exempt non-commercial use from constituting infringement.
UK courts have historically considered the purpose and character of the use, including commercial nature, as a factor in fair dealing exceptions.
Fair dealing exceptions are narrowly defined and do not broadly cover all non-commercial uses, maintaining the general rule of infringement.
Case law such as Ashdown v Telegraph Group Ltd (2001) confirmed that even non-commercial use can infringe if it doesn't fall under specific exceptions.

supporting.text: Fair dealing exceptions in U.K. law are limited and do not broadly permit use of copyrighted material simply because no profit is made.

attacks.text: Fair dealing exceptions in U.K. law are limited and do not broadly permit use of copyrighted material simply because no profit is made.
Non-commercial use is explicitly listed as a factor in fair dealing assessments under U.K. law, making lack of profit relevant to infringement claims.
Even in non-commercial cases, substantial use of copyrighted material without permission can still constitute infringement under U.K. fair dealing tests.
Many U.K. court rulings have dismissed copyright claims against non-profit educational or research uses, showing that lack of profit can provide protection.
Such rulings are context-specific and don't establish a universal rule that non-commercial use automatically prevents infringement claims.

supporting.text: Legal precedent in the U.K. has established that infringement can occur even in the absence of commercial benefit.

attacks.text: Legal precedent in the U.K. has established that infringement can occur even in the absence of commercial benefit.
The claim refers to fair use exceptions, which may apply for non-commercial purposes under certain conditions.
Fair use in the U.K. is narrowly defined and rarely applies to full reproductions of copyrighted works, regardless of commercial intent.
Many copyright holders do not pursue legal action against non-commercial infringements due to the cost and effort involved.
While enforcement may be inconsistent, the legal risk remains as rights holders can still pursue claims regardless of commercial impact.

supporting.text: The concept of 'fair use' in the U.K. is narrower than in some jurisdictions and does not generally cover non-commercial use without permission.

attacks.text: The concept of 'fair use' in the U.K. is narrower than in some jurisdictions and does not generally cover non-commercial use without permission.

The U.K. has 'fair dealing' provisions that explicitly allow limited use of copyrighted works without permission for purposes such as research, private study, criticism, or news reporting, even if no money is made.
Fair dealing in the U.K. is still subject to strict interpretation by courts, and not all non-commercial uses qualify, especially if they compete with the original work's market.
The Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 includes exceptions for non-commercial uses like education and parody, which can protect against infringement claims even without profit.
These exceptions are narrowly defined and require adherence to specific conditions, making them unreliable as blanket protections for all non-commercial uses.
